title: 107_hr5636
content: The Nurse Loan Forgiveness Act of 2002, also known as the Stafford Loans program, establishes loan forgiveness for nurses under section 428L of the Higher Education Act of 1965. The Nurse Loan Forgiveness Act of 2002 aims to encourage individuals to enter and stay in the nursing profession by offering loan forgiveness for registered nurses who work full-time for 3 consecutive years in approved healthcare facilities. The program assumes the obligation to repay a qualified loan amount for eligible borrowers who meet specific criteria and are not in default on their loans. The Nurse Loan Forgiveness Act of 2002 allows the Secretary to repay up to $5,000 of a loan after 3 years of nursing, with a maximum of $12,000 for nurses who work for 5 consecutive years. The Secretary will make payments on a first-come first-served basis, subject to appropriations availability. Loan amounts from section 428C can be considered qualified loan amounts if used to repay specific types of loans for eligible borrowers. The Secretary can issue regulations to implement this section. The section authorizes appropriations for loan repayments and prohibits borrowers from receiving double benefits for the same service. The Higher Education Act of 1965 is amended to include a new section on Direct Loans. The Higher Education Act of 1965 is amended to include a new section on Direct Loans, which includes loan forgiveness for nurses under SEC. 460A. The purpose of this section is to encourage individuals to enter and stay in the nursing profession by offering loan forgiveness for registered nurses who work full-time in approved healthcare facilities for 3 consecutive years. The program cancels the obligation to repay qualified loan amounts for Federal Direct Stafford Loans and Federal Direct Unsubsidized Stafford Loans. The Secretary may cancel up to $5,000 of a loan obligation after 3 years of nursing. For registered nurses meeting certain requirements, up to $12,000 can be canceled after 5 years of employment. Loan amounts are canceled based on specific criteria. The Secretary will cancel loan amounts on a first-come first-served basis, subject to availability of appropriations. Loan amounts from consolidation loans can be considered qualified only if used to repay specific types of loans for eligible borrowers. The Secretary is authorized to issue necessary regulations for implementation. The section specifies that no refunding of loan repayments is allowed. It also prevents borrowers from receiving double benefits for the same service under different programs. Appropriations are authorized for loan repayments for fiscal years 2003 and beyond.
